noun.description: A triangular staysail set forward of the forwardmost mast.
The projecting arm of a crane.

verb.description: (of an animal, especially a horse) stop and refuse to go on.
examples: he jibbed at the final fence

phrases: I like the cut of your jib, young fellow
He liked the cut of my jib, and I also went out of my way to prove myself as an intrepid reporter.
You can tell a man's character by the cut of his jib.
He is reputedly a fan of Western films and, going by the cut of his jib, country-and-western music.
Sir, I like the cut of your jib.
origin: Early 19th century: perhaps related to French regimber (earlier regiber) to buck, rear; compare with gibe.
